chapters.name: General design
chapters.text: VM is register based with dedicated accumulator register, which serves as an implicit operand to instructions.

chapters.name: Registers
chapters.text: Registers are wide enough to hold a single reference when working with objects. When used for primitive types, registers width should be considered as 64 bits. When used for object types, registers should be considered wide enough to hold a reference to an object. The scope of a register is function frame (also known as activation record). If instruction defines not all 64 bits of a register, undefined bits shall not be accessed in verified code. Register field width in instruction encoding could be 4 (16 addressable registers), 8 (256 registers) or 16 (65536 registers) bits.

chapters.name: Accumulator
chapters.text: Accumulator is a special register which is implicitly used by instructions as a source and/or destination operand. The main goal of using accumulator is to improve encoding density without losing much in performance. Therefore, the general intuition regarding accumulator usage is to utilize the accumulator as much as possible taking it as a source from previous instruction result and passing it to the next instruction in its destination operand. Moreover, when instruction has more than one source operands, the value which lives shorter should be passed through the accumulator. If it is profitable however, variations of instructions that don't write into the accumulator are also introduced. For example, moving arguments for `call.range` instruction may be done by register-to-register moves.

chapters.name: Calling sequence
chapters.text: On execution of a call bytecode a new function frame is created. All necessary arguments are copied from the caller frame onto the top of the callee frame such as the last argument is placed in the register with the largest index and the first argument is placed into the register with the index equal to the size of frame subtracted by the number of arguments. Accumulator value is considered as undefined and shall not be read in verified bytecode. On return, callee frame is destroyed. If function return value is non-void, it is passed to caller via accumulator. Otherwise accumulator content in caller frame is considered as undefined and shall not be read in verified bytecode.

chapters.name: Supported primitive types
chapters.text:
VM support operations on registers with i32 and i64 integral values. However, 8-bit and 16-bit integral values
can be loaded/stored into records and arrays with corresponding bytecodes. In that case, VM will extend/truncate
value to match storage size with i32. Similarly, passing an 8-bit or 16-bit value to a function can be emulated by
passing a value, which is zero or sign-extended to i32.
VM support operations on registers with f32 and f64 values, which corresponds to IEEE-754 single and double precision
floating-point represenation.
Primitive data type of a register is not tracked by VM and is interpreted by separate bytecodes.
Integral values are not inherently signed or unsigned, signedness is interpreted by bytecodes as well.
If bytecode treats register value as signed integer, it uses two's complement representation.
To denote that bytecode treats register values as unsigned integer, u32/u64 notation is used.
For moves, loads and stores it is not always possible to denote a type of result, because it depends on type
of source object. In that case, bNN notation is used, where NN is bit size of result. Therefore, for example,
b64 is a union of f64 and i64.

### Floating-point literals

Decimal floating-point literals can have the following parts:

- Sign ("`+`" or "`-`")
- Whole number part
- Decimal point
- Fractional part
- Exponent indicator ("`e`")
- Exponent sign
- Exponent

Decimal floating-point literals must have at least one digit and either decimal point or exponent part.

Special values:

- Positive zero (+0.0, hexadecimal representation is `0x0000000000000000`)
- Negative zero (-0.0, hexadecimal representation is `0x8000000000000000`)
- Minimal positive value (4.9E-324, hexadecimal representation is `0x0000000000000001`)
- Maximal negative value (-4.9E-324, hexadecimal representation is `0x8000000000000001`)
- Maximal positive value (1.7976931348623157e308, hexadecimal representation is `0x7fefffffffffffff`)
- Minimal negative value (-1.7976931348623157e308, hexadecimal representation is `0xffefffffffffffff`)
- Positive infinity (hexadecimal representation is `0x7ff0000000000000`)
- Negative infinity (hexadecimal representation is `0xfff0000000000000`)
- Not a number - set of all NaN values (one of hexadecimal representations is `0x7ff8000000000000`)

chapters.name: Language-dependent types
chapters.text: Panda VM supports type hierarchies according to the language it executes. That way, creation (or loading from constant pool) of strings, arrays, exception objects results into an object of type native to language, including inheritance relations.

chapters.name: Dynamically-typed languages support
chapters.text: Panda VM supports languages with dynamic types. It represents dynamic values through special 'any' values, which wraps a value itself (both primitive and objects) and corresponding type info. VM tracks type of registers, that hold 'any' value, whether they are primitive or not. Virtual registers and accumulator are wide enough to hold 'any' value. When VM executes code inside dynamically-typed language context, regular static instructions also may be used.

properties.description: Use an id which resolves into a type constant.
Use an id which resolves into a method constant.
Use an id which resolves into a string constant.
Use an id which resolves into a constant literalarray.
Use an id which resolves into a field reference.
Pass control to the callee method.
Pass control to the callee method via virtual call.
Pass control to the caller method.
Suspend current method and pass control to the caller one.
Pass control to another bytecode in a current method.
Operate based on computed condition, otherwise is no operation.
Perform floating point operation.
Operates on 'any' values.
May operate on 'any' values depending on language context.
Creates objects of type depending on language context.
May initialize type instance during execution.
Use the immedate number after opcode of length 8-bit or 16-bit as ic slot.
Use the immedate number after opcode of length 8-bit as jit ic slot.
The intruction occupies one ic slot.
The intruction occupies two ic slots.
The instruction occupies ic slots of 8 bit width.
The instruction occupies ic slots of 16 bit width.
The instruction occupies ic slots of both 8 and 16 bit width.
The throw instruction can throw an excepton only if certain conditions are met.

Indicates that the instruction takes some consective registers as inputs. The start register of these consective inputs is the last register of the instruction. The number of consective inputs is the last immediate of the instruction.

Indicates that the instruction takes some consective registers as inputs. The start register of these consective inputs is the last register of the instruction. The number of consective inputs is the last immediate of the instruction plus 1.

exceptions.description: Bytecode throws NullPointerException in case of null reference as a source.
Bytecode throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if index is out of bounds of an array.
Bytecode throws NegativeArraySizeException if index is less than zero.
Bytecode throws ArrayStoreException if element isn't instance of array's element type.
Bytecode throws AbstractMethodError if resolved method has no implementation.
Bytecode throws ArithmeticException if the divisor is 0.
Bytecode throws ClassCastException if type cast failed.
Bytecode throws NoClassDefFoundError if type cast failed.
Bytecode throws OutOfMemoryError if failed to allocate object.
Bytecode throws ExceptionInInitializerError if unexpected exception occurred in a static initializer.
Bytecode may throw an error if an exception occures in the called bytecode.
Bytecode's primary role is to throw provided exception object.
Bytecode may throw NoClassDefFoundError if failed to resolve id.

verification.description: Instruction is always valid.
First operand contains a reference to an array.
First operand contains a reference to an object (other than array).
First operand contains a reference to an array of elements of type corresponding to bytecode.
First operand contains a value of i32 type.
First operand contains a value of type corresponding to bytecode.
First operand contains a reference to an object or null.
Second operand contains a value of i32 type.
Second operand contains a reference to an object (other than array).
Second operand contains a value of type corresponding to bytecode.
Accumulator contains a value of i32 type.
Accumulator contains a value of type corresponding to bytecode.
Accumulator type is compatible with method return type.
First operand contains a reference to an instance of class Throwable or of a subclass of Throwable.
Accumulator contains a reference to an object or null.
Type_id operand must correspond to an array type.
Type_id operand must correspond to an object type (other than array).
Type_id operand must correspond to any object type.
Method_id must resolve to a static method or into initializer for a type other than one-dimensional array.
Method_id must resolve to a non-static method.
Method_id must resolve to a method that has implementation.
Method_id must resolve to a method which is accessible.
Id must resolve into a constant-pool string.
Id must resolve into a constant literalarray.
Arguments provided to a method must be of compatible types.
Method_id must resolve into initializer for a type other than one-dimensional array.
Branch target should point to a beginning of an instruction of the same method.
Field_id must resolve to a non-static object field.
Field_id must resolve to a static field.
Field_id must resolve to a field of size corresponding to bytecode.
Instruction valid only for dynamically-typed language context.

isa_information.description: The last encoding number of various ISA. It should be maintained as long as ISA changes.

prefixes.name: deprecated
prefixes.description: deprecated instructions but are keeped for compatibility.

groups.title: constant object loaders
groups.description: instructions which operate on constant objects.

instructions.sig: callruntime.definesendableclass imm1:u16, method_id, literalarray_id, imm2:u16, v:in:top
callthis3 imm:u8, v1:in:top, v2:in:top, v3:in:top, v4:in:top
defineclasswithbuffer imm1:u16, method_id, literalarray_id, imm2:u16, v:in:top
deprecated.defineclasswithbuffer method_id, imm1:u16, imm2:u16, v1:in:top, v2:in:top

groups.title: Load accumulator from string constant pool
groups.description: Load string specified by id into accumulator. In dynamically-typed language context load string as 'any' value.

groups.title: jump operations
groups.description: Transfer execution to an instruction at offset bytes from the beginning of the current instruction. Offset is sign extended to the size of instruction address.

groups.title: Dynamic load accumulator from register
groups.description: Move 'any' value from register to accumulator

groups.title: Dynamic store accumulator
groups.description: Move 'any' value from accumulator to register

groups.title: Dynamic load accumulator from immediate
groups.description: Move immediate as 'any' value to accumulator
